questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, he appears diaphoretic and anxious. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, and cardiac enzymes are elevated. Coronary angiography reveals normal coronary arteries, but left ventriculography shows apical ballooning with preserved basal contractility. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in his legs. An echocardiogram reveals a dilated left ventricle with reduced ejection fraction. Genetic testing is performed, a mutation is likely to be identified in which of the following genes?

A student is preparing for a seminar on the topic ‘Endocarditis’ and wants to include slides describing the different types of vegetations seen in various endocardial diseases. Which of the following slides would be an accurate description of the vegetation and the condition it is associated with ?

options.label: A
options.text: A) Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are typically small, friable, sterile and composed of fibrin, platelets.

options.label: B
options.text: B) Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are large, verrucous, and primarily consist of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms.

options.label: C
options.text: C) Nonbacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (NBTE) commonly presents with small, non- sterile vegetations composed mainly of fibrin and platelets.

options.label: D
options.text: D) Libman-Sacks Endocarditis is characterized by tiny, marantic vegetations consisting of fibrin and micro-organism.

questions.correct_answer: B. B) Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are large, verrucous, and primarily consist of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms.
questions.explanation:
Vegetation Characteristics

Infective Endocarditis (IE)

Nonbacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (NBTE)

Libman-Sacks Endocarditis

Rheumatic Heart Disease

Composition

Largel, friable masses composed of fibrin, platelets, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells.

Small, sterile vegetations composed mainly of fibrin and platelets.

Small, marantic vegetations composed of fibrin and immune complexes.

Small, warty vegetations composed primarily of fibrin and inflammatory cells.

Location

Form on damaged endocardial surfaces, particularly heart valves, in response to bacteremia.

Occur on cardiac valves or endocardium, typically in the setting of hypercoagulable states or advanced malignancies.

Form on the mitral or aortic valve leaflets, typically along the line of closure.

Develop on heart valves, particularly the mitral and aortic valves, as a sequela of rheumatic fever.

Microorganisms

Microorganisms adhere to the fibrin-platelet matrix, proliferate, and trigger an inflammatory response.

Lack inflammatory cells or microorganisms and are not associated with infection.

Not applicable, as vegetations are sterile.

Not applicable, as vegetations are primarily a result of autoimmune-mediated damage.

Clinical Complications

Prone to embolization, leading to complications such as stroke or systemic infection. Can cause valve dysfunction, contributing to heart failure.

Can lead to embolic complications similar to those seen in Infective Endocarditis.

May lead to valvular regurgitation or embolic events.

May lead to valvular stenosis or regurgitation, contributing to heart failure and other complications.

Histological Features

Echocardiography reveals irregular masses attached to the endocardium.

Not applicable, as vegetations are sterile.

Histologically characterized by the presence of fibrinoid material and immune cell infiltrates.

Histologically characterized by the presence of fibrous tissue and chronic inflammatory infiltrates.

questions.text: A 25-year-old girl with a history of asthma presents with wheezing and rhinitis. Lab reports show eosinophilia and antibodies against neutrophil myeloperoxidase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Churg Strauss syndrome

Churg-Strauss syndrome (also called allergic granulomatosis and angiitis) is a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis classically associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral eosinophilia, extravascular necrotizing granulomas, and eosinophilic infiltration of vessels and tissues.

 
  • New name: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

Vessels affected

Small to medium sized arteries

Clinical feature

Asthma, allergic rhinitis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis and eosinophilic granulomas

Diagnosis

p-ANCA/MPO antibodies +ve, Eosinophilia, Biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation

Management

Cortoicosteroids

questions.text: Arrange the following steps of atherosclerosis formation in the correct order. Endothelial injury and dysfunction Accumulation of lipoproteins Platelet adhesion and factor release Smooth muscle and collagen formation
A 55-year-old female presents with hematuria, hemoptysis, and sinusitis. Renal biopsy reveals pauci-immune necrotising crescentic glomerulonephritis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
ANCA pattern

Diseases

c-ANCA
  • Granulomatosis with polyangitis

p-ANCA
  • Microscopic polyangitis
  • Churg Strauss syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Buerger disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the media with focal transmural necrotising lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Segmental thrombosing vasculitis affecting small and medium-sized arteries

options.label: D
options.text: Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasa vasorum

questions.correct_answer: B. Segmental thrombosing vasculitis affecting small and medium-sized arteries

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a high fever persisting for five days, along with bilateral conjunctival injection, strawberry tongue, and rash on the trunk and extremities. There is also swelling and erythema of the hands and feet. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Weibel-Palade bodies consist of which of the following components?
questions.explanation:
Contents

Vascular functions

Von Willebrand factor

  

Thrombosis

Factor VIIIa

t-PA

Fibrinolysis

P-selectin

  

Inflammation

IL-8

Eotaxin

α-1,3-fucosyltransferase VI

CD63 (Lamp 3)

 Exocytosis

Endothelin 1

  

Vasoconstriction

Endothelin converting enzyme

Calcitonin gene-related peptide

Vasodilation

Angiopoietin 2

Angiogenesis

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with cyanosis and respiratory distress. Physical examination reveals a murmur and a palpable liver edge. Echocardiography demonstrates multiple intracardiac masses located primarily in the ventricular walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a cause for restrictive cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation:
CAUSES OF RESTRICTIVE CARDIOMYOPATHY
  • Amyloidosis (Option B)
  • Hemochromatosis (Option A)
  • Radiation
  • Scleroderma
  • Tropical endomyocardial fibrosis
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome (Löffler’s endocarditis)
  • Sarcoidosis (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major criterion according to Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Heart Disease?
questions.explanation:
Major Criteria

Minor Criteria
  • Carditis (Option B)
  • Polyarthritis (Option A)
  • Chorea (Sydenham’s)
  • Subcutaneous nodules (Option C)
  • Erythema marginatum

Clinical

  • Fever
  • Polyarthralgia
  • Prolonged PR interval

Lab

  • Increased ESR
  • Increased CRP

Minor criteria present in previous episodes or evidence of previous rheumatic fever

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most likely present in the myocardial biopsy of a Rheumatic Heart disease patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, Anitschkow cells and fibroblasts in all layers of the heart

options.label: C
options.text: Calcific nodules on the valve leaflets

options.label: D
options.text: Disruption of the endothelial lining of blood vessels

questions.correct_answer: B. Areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, Anitschkow cells and fibroblasts in all layers of the heart

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the vegetation found in Infective Endocarditis compared to other conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are typically small, friable, sterile and composed of fibrin, and platelets.

options.label: B
options.text: Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are large, verrucous, and primarily consist of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms.

options.label: C
options.text: Nonbacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (NBTE) commonly presents with small, non-sterile vegetations composed mainly of fibrin and platelets.

options.label: D
options.text: Libman-Sacks Endocarditis is characterised by tiny, marantic vegetations consisting of fibrin and micro-organisms.

questions.correct_answer: B. Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are large, verrucous, and primarily consist of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms.
questions.explanation:
Rheumatic heart disease

Infective Endocarditis 

Non-bacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (Option C)

Libman-Sacks Endocarditis  (Option D)

Small and warty

Large and bulky (Option B) (Option A ruled out)

Small and friable 

Medium sized

Along lines of closure

Upper surface of cusps

Along lines of closure

Both surface of valves (M/C-lower surface)

Sterile

Non- sterile

Sterile

Sterile

Emboli -

Emboli +/-

Emboli +++

Emboli -

questions.text: Which viral organism is most commonly associated with myocarditis?

Match the following pathologies with the correct pattern of vegetative endocarditis caused by them: 1. Rheumatic Heart Disease a) Small, warty, sterile vegetations along the line of closure of valve leaflets 2. Infective Endocarditis b) Small, bland, sterile vegetation along the line of closure 3.Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) c) Small or medium-sized sterile vegetations on both sides of valvular leaflets. 4. Libman-Sacks endocarditis d) Large, bulky, infected, friable, irregular mass along the line of closure or on valvular cusps.
questions.explanation:
Condition

Vegetations and site

Rheumatic heart disease

Small, warty, sterile vegetations along the line of closure of valve leaflets.

Infective Endocarditis
  • Large, bulky, infected, friable, irregular mass along the line of closure or on valvular cusps, more on the atrial side.
  • They cause damage to cordae tendinae and papillary muscles.

Non-bacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis

Small, bland, sterile vegetation along the line of closure.

Libman-Sacks Endocarditis

(Endocarditis of SLE)

Small or medium-sized sterile vegetations on either or both sides of valvular leaflets, most commonly on the lower side.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a predisposing factor for Nonbacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (NBTE)?

options.label: D
options.text: Traumatic injury to the heart valves

questions.correct_answer: D. Traumatic injury to the heart valves

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with a history of multiple tumours in various organs, including the brain, retina, and kidneys. On examination, retinal angiomas and cerebellar hemangioblastomas are noted. The patient's family history reveals similar manifestations in relatives. Which of the following lesions is commonly associated with this syndrome?
Which of the following best describes using Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) in myocardial infarction?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to measure blood flow in coronary arteries

options.label: B
options.text: It helps visualize viable myocardial tissue after an infarction.

options.label: C
options.text: It acts as an anticoagulant to prevent clot formation.

options.label: D
options.text: It assists in the diagnosis of arrhythmias following a heart attack.

questions.correct_answer: B. It helps visualize viable myocardial tissue after an infarction.

questions.text: Which histopathological feature would not be expected in the myocardium within the first 24 hours after the infarction onset?
At what phase of myocardial infarction does the myocardium exhibit Mottling with a yellow-tan infarct center?
questions.explanation:
Time

Gross Features

Light Microscope

Electron Microscope

Reversible Injury

0– 1/2 hour

None

None

Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen loss; mitochondrial swelling

Irreversible Injury

1/2 –4 hours

None

Usually none; variable waviness of fibres at the border; myocyte vacuolisation

Sarcolemmal disruption;

mitochondrial amorphous densities (Calcium in mitochondria)

4–12 hours
(Option A)

Occasional dark mottling

Early coagulative necrosis, oedema, haemorrhage

  

12–24 hours

Dark mottling

Ongoing coagulative necrosis; pyknosis of nuclei; myocyte hypereosinophilia; marginal

contraction band necrosis; early neutrophilic infiltrate

  

1–3 days
(Option B)

Mottling with yellow-tan infarct

centre

Coagulative necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations; brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils (Acute inflammation)

  

3–7 days

Hyperemic border; central

yellow-tan softening

Beginning disintegration of dead myofibers, with dying neutrophils; early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border (Chronic inflammation)

  

7–10 days
(Option C)

Maximally yellow-tan and soft, with depressed red-tan margins

Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins (Repair)

  

10–14 days

Red-gray depressed infarct borders

Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition

  

2–8 weeks
(Option D)

Grey-white scar, progressive from the border toward the core of the infarct

Increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity

  

>2 months

Scarring complete

Dense collagenous scar

questions.text: What histopathological changes are typically observed during the reversible phase of myocardial infarction? Mitochondrial swelling Sarcolemmal disruption Relaxation of myofibrils
questions.explanation:
HPE changes in MI

Reversible injury

Irreversible injury

Earliest change in
Electron microscopy

Relaxation of myofibrils (Statement 3), Mitochondrial swelling (Statement 1)

Sarcolemmal disruption (Statement 2), Mitochondrial amorphous densities.

Earliest change in
Light microscopy

None

The waviness of cardiac fibres and myocyte vacuolisation.

questions.text: In a patient with acute myocardial infarction, which of the following is a characteristic change in LDH isoenzyme levels indicative of myocardial damage in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In healthy individuals

LDH2>>LDH1

In MI patients

LDH1>>LDH2

Isoenzymes

Location

Isoenzymes of LDH

LDH - 1

Mainly in heart & RBC

LDH - 2

WBC, (small amounts in heart and RBC)

LDH - 3

Lungs

LDH - 4

Kidneys & Pancreas; Placenta (in pregnancy)

LDH - 5

Liver & skeletal muscles

Isoenzymes of Creatinine kinase

CK - MM

Skeletal muscle & heart

CK - MB

Heart

CK - BB

Brain

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw, along with diaphoresis and anxiety. His vital signs show a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, heart rate of 110 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. An ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI). Which of the following biomarkers is most reliable for confirming myocardial injury in this condition?
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the pathologic changes in right-sided heart failure?

options.label: B
options.text: Pretibial oedema is the hallmark of right-sided heart failure.

options.label: C
options.text: Fibrosis in periportal areas of the liver

options.label: D
options.text: Congestive splenomegaly due to portal hypertension

questions.correct_answer: C. Fibrosis in periportal areas of the liver

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with a rapidly expanding, clearly defined, bright red lesion on the face. Upon examination, the lesion feels soft, yields to pressure, and temporarily loses color when pressure is applied. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is an intermediate-grade vascular tumour?
questions.explanation:
Type

Conditions

Benign Neoplasms, Developmental and Acquired Conditions
  • Hemangioma
    • Capillary hemangioma
    • Cavernous hemangioma
    • Pyogenic granuloma
  • Lymphangioma
    • Simple (capillary) lymphangioma
    • Cavernous lymphangioma (cystic hygroma)
  • Glomus tumor
  • Vascular ectasias
    • Nevus flammeus
    • Spider telangiectasia (arterial spider)
    • Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasis (Osler-Weber-Rendu disease)
  • Reactive vascular proliferations
    • Bacillary angiomatosis

Intermediate-Grade Neoplasms
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Hemangioendothelioma

Malignant Neoplasms
  • Angiosarcoma
  • Hemangiopericytoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden-onset severe abdominal pain radiating to his back. On physical examination, a pulsatile mass is palpated in his abdomen. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. Based on the clinical presentation and risk factors, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
